title: 106_hr4795
content: The "Homeowners Rebate Act of 2000" allows for payment of distributive shares from mutual mortgage insurance fund reserves. The "Homeowners Rebate Act of 2000" allows for distribution of surplus reserves from the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund to mortgagors whose mortgages were insured for 7 years or more before termination, in accordance with sound actuarial and accounting practices. The "Homeowners Rebate Act of 2000" authorizes the Secretary to distribute surplus reserves from the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund to eligible mortgagors in a fair manner, with limitations on the amount based on scheduled premiums and a requirement for application within 6 years of termination. The Secretary will transfer surplus reserves to the General Surplus Account if the mortgagor does not apply for payment within 6 years. The determination of surplus is subject to the capital ratio requirement under the National Housing Act. The Secretary will transfer surplus reserves to the General Surplus Account if the mortgagor does not apply for payment within 6 years, subject to the capital ratio requirement under the National Housing Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress evaluating the adequacy of the capital ratio requirement for ensuring the safety and soundness of the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will determine distributable shares for mortgages within 3 months of the Act's enactment and make payments to ensure the safety of the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund. The Insurance Fund was terminated by paying off the mortgage early, requiring a distributable share to be paid to the mortgagor under the National Housing Act, with no share paid upon termination of the insurance obligation.
